H0.text: The centrifugal force created by rapid rotation is what keeps stars such as the Sun from collapsing under their own self-gravity.

H1.text: The electrical repulsion of nuclei in the plasma keeps stars such as the Sun from collapsing from their own self‑gravity.

H2.text: The gravitational pull created by orbiting planets is what keeps stars such as the Sun from collapsing from their own self‑gravity.

H3.text: The outward pressure created by nuclear fusion keeps stars such as the Sun from collapsing under their own self‑gravity.

A5.text: If the star has a massive nearby companion object, tidal forces come into play as well, which distort the star into a scalene shape if rotation alone would make it a spheroid.

A6.text: The outward force due to the pressure gradient within the star is exactly balanced by the inward force due to gravity.
